sourceDesc.p: his is the feature-file for the passive forms.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

item.label: t- prefix passive / tt- prefix passive - tfataḥ or ttəfataḥ
t- infix passive – ntaqal (normally for verbs that have n as a first radical)

cit.quote: He was killed in a car accident

wib:featureValueObservation.note: None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in- (Pickett 2005:245).
None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in- (Pickett 2005:245).
None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in- (Pickett 2005:245).
None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in- (Pickett 2005:245).
None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in- (Pickett 2005:245).
None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in- (Pickett 2005:245).

cit.quote: it is cut, it gets cut

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Forms VII (the n- prefix) derives the passive and also, in the case of some verbs, denotes acquiescence to an action which was precipitated by others, or by a situation, e.g. nṣaraf/yinṣarif lit. ‘to leave’, but in ʿAmmānī (as in the Levant in general) its meaning is similar to British English ‘to buzz off’. Forms V and VI (t-prefix) also function to derive passives, and, in the case of Form VI, there is a sense of reciprocity.

La forme passive de ʔakal „manger‟, comme dans de nombreuses variétés levantines, ne fait pas intervenir la forme VII mais une forme préfixée par t- dont le schème est similaire à la forme VI : ttākal-yittākal „être mangé‟. (Herin 2010: 330)

In the Negev, use of the internal passive has entirely disappeared. In Az, only two vestiges of the internal passive were preserved, having God as their subject, namely rizig, yarzag "to make a living, to be blessed with", and xulug, yuxlug "to be born, be created" wich exist alongside their active counterparts. (Shawabah 2012:263).

In the Negev, use of the internal passive has entirely disappeared. In Az, only two vestiges of the internal passive were preserved, having God as their subject, namely rizig, yarzag "to make a living, to be blessed with", and xulug, yuxlug "to be born, be created" wich exist alongside their active counterparts. (Shawabah 2012:263).

cit.quote: it is said, it is called

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from examples
Maltese orthography: inbela'
Maltese orthography: steraq
Maltese orthography: ittiekel
This form is a t-prefix passive with a Form I stem that transformed to a Form VI

cit.quote: he got robbed / he got stolen

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Maltese orthography: ġie misruq
This type of passive is extremely rare
Benkato (2013) does not attest apophonic passive forms

cit.quote: he was bitten by a snake

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form VIII as a passive form is only applicable to some verbs; Form VII is the normal means of passivization (Holes 2006)
Form VIII as a passive form is only applicable to some verbs; Form VII is the normal means of passivization

cit.quote: when it has been baled out and the timbers have tightened

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The internal passive occurs commonly in a few fixed phrases, e.g. wāḥid yigāl lih ‘someone called…’, wlidt (A)/xlukt (B villages) ‘I was born’; otherwise sporadically e.g. alḥīn ruwyat, tinǧaḥ ‘now it [crop] has been watered, it'll grow’ (B village); lēn yinzaf u yisikk illōḥ ‘when it has been baled out and the timbers have tightened’ (A) (Holes 2007).

In Bahrain, the internal passive occurs relatively rarely, but much more commonly in the BV dialects (Baḥārna Village Dialects) than the A (ʕArab Dialects) or BU (Baḥārna Urban Dialects) (Holes 2016).

cit.quote: now it [crop] has been watered, it'll grow (B village)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The internal passive occurs commonly in a few fixed phrases, e.g. wāḥid yigāl lih ‘someone called…’, wlidt (A)/xlukt (B villages) ‘I was born’; otherwise sporadically e.g. alḥīn ruwyat, tinǧaḥ ‘now it [crop] has been watered, it'll grow’ (B village); lēn yinzaf u yisikk illōḥ ‘when it has been baled out and the timbers have tightened’ (A) (Holes 2007).

In Bahrain, the internal passive occurs relatively rarely, but much more commonly in the BV dialects (Baḥārna Village Dialects) than the A (ʕArab Dialects) or BU (Baḥārna Urban Dialects) (Holes 2016).

The internal passive occurs in normal speech only in a few fixed phrases, and usually in the imperfect, e.g. wāḥid yigāl lih ‘someone called…’, wlidt ‘I was born’, but more commonly in proverbs, e.g. iḏa ṭigg ilxašim, ihmalat ilʿēn ‘if the nose is struck, the eye weeps’(Holes 2007).
The patterns for the apophonic passive are fiʕil and yifʕal
The apophonic passive only occurs in some fixed expressions, e.g. tislam īdēkum 'May your hands be blessed'.
No information is available about the imperfective form of the passive.
"very frequent use of internal passive". No example provided.
No example provided.
The n-prefix is more frequent than the t-prefix.
The t-passive is only used when "C1 is phonetically too close to the generally preferred passive marker n-".

cit.quote: the car wants to be washed

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The scheme alCvCCvC is also employed for the passive: "it is broken" can both be ankasar and alkassar.
infix t with some verbs whose first root consonant is n or l.
There are very few verbs which also have n-prefix: nḍṛab il a été frappé (Cohen 1975)
Mion_2021_page 117
The apophonic passive is no longer productive and restricted to a fixed number of verbs (Ritt-Benmimoun 2024:331)
Apart from the n-prefix there exists a fixed number of verbs which exhibit apophonic passive (Ritt-Benmimoun 2024:331)
t-prefix to a lesser extent
In Hadrami Arabic, passivisation is very much restricted to a few verbs and situations in which it is not important to define the agent.

cit.quote: jābōh min il-wādi baʕd il-ʕša. iḏ̣-ḏ̣āhir innuh gbuṣ
They brought him from the valley after ʕša time. It seems that he was bitten/stung
the patch (of the field) was waterlogged

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Although there are many examples of the apophonic passive, these can still be considered as remnants. The passive is mainly formed by using verb forms V and VIII.
Although in some verbs forms V, VII, VIII have passive meaning, the passive mood itself occurrs remarkably frequently.
The apophonic passive tends to be replaced by derived verb forms V, VII, VIII.

cit.quote: He would be left to his own devices
